title: The contrast between the tables of stone and the tables of the heart derives from 2 Cor.3:3, and was commonly employed, sometimes with reference to the difference between the Old Law of the Ten Commandments and the New Law of Charity (see Goldsmith, p.100, n.16), sometimes to distinguish between formal knowledge of and heartfelt commitment to God's law (see Policraticus, IV.vi (p.24)). That the love of the New Law represents the perfect fulfilment of the Old was also an idea Biblical in origin
